U PLANS SESSION FOR HOSPITAL, NURSING HOME HEADS
GRAND FORKS, N. D. -- The eighth annual School for Hospital and Nursing Home
Administrators is scheduled April 12-13 at the University of North Dakota. The school
is being jointly sponsored by the North Dakota Hospital Association, the UND General
Extension Division and the College of Business and Public Administration.
Sessions at the University Center will be conducted by members of the UND
faculty who are trained in the fields of management and human relations. Modern
management techniques will be the special concern of the two-day school. "Buzz sessions"
have been included on the program to enable administrators and their representatives
to discuss mutual problems.
Registration will be held in the University Center Fireside Lounge at
8:15 a.m. April 12. Fees are $10 for the first registration from an institution and
$7.50 for each succeeding one from the same institution. Information about hotel and
motel accommodations may be obtained from Harvey C» Hanson, executive director. North
Dakota Hospital Association, Grand Forks. Program brochures and pre-registration
forms are available through the University General Extension Division.

U STUDIES ROLE OF EDUCATIONAL RADIO, TV
GRAND FORKS, N. D. -- A recent Ford Foundation grant of $38,000 to National
Educational Radio, a division of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters,
for a comprehensive study of the status and needs of educational radio in the United
States is expected to provide beneficial effects for local educational radio stations
such as the University of North Dakota's broadcasting service, KFJM.
"This grant is a recognition that educational radio needs developing," said
Myron Curry, director of KFJM and closed circuit television at UND. "For KFJM and other
educational radio services, the findings of the survey can assist in development of
patterns and goals. We will have data available which has never been available before."
